I like this book for it exceptionally beautiful writing. One should have a very sharp imagination to make an exciting story  of the life of an insurance agent. I was not ready to give the book its well-deserved five stars since I was a little disappointed by its vague ending which  is somehow  characteristic for my beloved author Mr. Boyd/

The plot is dishevelled and waffly. The narrator is a bit dull and it is difficult to care what befalls him . The villians were better written . Jupiter was the most interesting character in the novel.
Not the best of Boyd, but very readable just the same. A convincing story with unexpected turnings. One for the archives.

William Boyd's 1998 detective-genre novel centers on a complicated insurance fraud scheme set in London and the efforts of Lorimer Black, an up-and-coming insurance loss adjuster, to sort out the scam and collect the substantial bonus he expects for his good work. The book has all the ingredients of a good read, a gorgeous, if hard -- to  -- get,  girl; greedy, astronomically  rich, Londoners; a rock star and a dowager; fish farms and drug smugglers, not to mention Black's family. Black, born  Milomre (Milo for short)  Blocj,  the youngest son of a Transnistrian gypsy family gamely working its way into middleclass from the margins of London's economy, took an English name and seems to have things going his way until one thing after another goes wrong. But, as always in such tales, there is a way out and Black/Blocj, equipped as he is by wit, pluck and luck, finds it. Boyd writes well. He doesn't patronize. I had to read the novel with The Concise Oxford English Dictionary at my elbow and it failed me on several occasions. He's concocted an engaging, if not always easy to follow or believe, plot. He makes a fetish of precise, detailed physical descriptions of the persons and places that occupy his pages. E.g., describing the patrons at the Cafe Matisse, one of Black's favorite restaurants, Black sees:"A middle-aged couple - style: Eastern European intellectual - the man looking uncannily like Bertol Brecht, both bespectacled, both in drab zip-up waterproof jackets. A table of four consumptive hippies, three men with lank hair and poor beards and a girl (rolling her own), bead-swagged with a flower tattooed on her throat . . . . the obligatory lost-waif couple, two chalk-faced girls, black-clad, talking worriedly in furious whispers -- too young, in trouble, pimp fodder." All in all, the book is less, by a fair amount, than the sum of its parts. Read it on a plane or at the beach, no need to save it for a rainy day when you are willing to engage a more serious book, e.g. Boyd's "An Ice-Cream War" or "Brazzaville Beach."End Note. My rating: three stars. In the hands of a new writer or one less accomplished than Boyd, I might well give it four. As this indicates, my ratings take into account what I think the writer is capable of as well as what the author produces. Boyd, as he has shown many times, is capable of better.

summary:
From the award-winning author of A Good Man Africa and An Ice-Cream War comes Armadillo, a brilliant satirical noir set in contemporary London.

To his colleagues, Lorimer Black, the handsome, mild-mannered insurance adjuster rising through the ranks of his London firm, is known as the guy who has it all: the sleek suits, the enviable status. But when Lorimer arrives at a routine business appointment and finds his client hanging from a water pipe, his life spirals out of control. His company car is blowtorched after he investigates a fire at a luxury hotel. He becomes the fall guy of a new colleague who puts the company in the red and the victim of a vicious attack by the possessive husband of a mysterious actress.  
        
As Lorimer becomes increasingly entangled in an apparent conspiracy that involves everyone he knows, his own past comes to light. A brilliant satirical noir, Armadillo confirms Boyd's place as England's most versatile, sublime novelist.
